subject: creative use of JUnit
msgSnippet: Hy, I ve been using JUnit for unit tests quite successfully for some time now. Now I ve started working on a framework to test the configuration & setup of a
messageBody:
Hy,

I've been using JUnit for unit tests quite successfully for some time now.
Now I've started working on a framework to test the configuration & setup
of a running system. I've noticed several similarities between the
framework I built and JUnit and I plan to port this framework on top of
JUnit, now I've got some questions on the nature of JUnit that I didn't
need to know until now.

Is the number returned by Test.countTestCases() binding? I ask because my
check framework can't tell in advance how many checks it will have to do
(it could but that would increase development effort quite a lot, and I'd
like to avoid that). Do current TestRunners depend on a pre-defined
structure of the test? Another difference of my check framework to JUnit
is that checks may again initiate checks (they provide an object to be
tested and a central instance decides which tests to run on this object).

Anyone got any ideas on the general design of such a beast or knows wether
such a thing was already attempted on top of JUnit?

regards
Joachim Sauer

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
